participants.participant: Christian Mulliez, Executive Vice President, Administration and Finance
Jean-Jacques Lebel, President, Consumer Products Division
Marc Menesguen, Managing Director, Strategic Marketing
Nicolas Hieronimus, Managing Director, Luxury Products Division
Brigitte Liberman, General Manager, Active Cosmetics

plist.p: Good morning and welcome to this meeting for the presentation of the 2010 results. I would like to begin by introducing not only those who are seated with me here but all of the other members of the Steering Committee of the group. I will begin with the people on the podium.

To my right Jean-Jacques Lebel for Consumer Products; Marc Menesguen for Luxury Products, who is taking on the responsibility of Strategic Marketing, I hope you will have questions to ask him on the scope of this new mission; Brigitte Liberman, who is the Head of the Active Cosmetics Division. To my right Christian Mulliez, whom you know well, in-charge of Finances; and Nicolas Hieronimus, who was the Head of the Professional Products Division, and who since the 1st of January has now taken over from Marc and is the Head of the Luxury Products Division.

In the room, we have Laurent Attal, who is the new Head of Research and Innovation for the L'Oréal group. An Verhulst is the new Head of the Professional Products Division. We did not asked An to present the 2010 results, since she was not really responsible for that but she was the Head of the North American branch, which accounts for about 40% of the profits of the group. And Sara Ravella is the new Head of Communications and our Head of Operations. Beatrice Dautresme is the Head of External Relations and she is with us up until the end of February. And we have the – you have Jochen Zaumseil, Head of Asia Pacific, our areas of conquest. And Geoff Skingsley, whom I forgot, is Head of Human Resources and both go together of course. And Alexandre Popoff is the boss for Latin America and Africa and the Middle East. And Frederic Rozé is not here today because he is in New York. You know that in the United States you waste no time in doing business, so he is over there.
So you have the whole team. We're going to begin the meeting. And as usual, I will ask Jean Régis to explain to us about the practical arrangements.

Good morning, ladies. Good morning, gentlemen. As usual, before beginning the presentations, I would like to remind you of a few practical details regarding the meeting. You'll have found when you entered the room headphones for interpretation. The channels for the two languages available are shown on the middle screen. I suggest that you switch now to the channel of your choice. The entrance hall to this room is equipped with WiFi antennas to enable you, if you wish to connect with the outside world from the entrance hall. So while you are in this auditorium, please make sure now that your cell phones are switched off.

At the entrance to the room, you were given the booklets with the figures that Mr. Mulliez will be commenting and Mr. Agon's booklet will be – with the tables will be distributed during the break. There are many of you attending this meeting and several of you are in the second room, which will be treated absolutely in the same way as this one, especially during the question-and-answer part.
I would like to ask Suzie who is next door, in the second room, to tell us whether she can hear us well and whether everything is okay?
Yes, we hear you well and everything is okay.

Fine. So, thank you, Suzie. On your seat, you will also have found a card on which you may ask your questions initially in writing. Do not hesitate to do so. The hostesses will be passing around during the presentations to pick up your question cards. Of course, after the break, you will also be able to ask your questions orally whether you are in room one or two. However, please state your name and company before asking your question.

The whole of this meeting will be broadcast live or is being broadcast live on your dedicated Web site, loreal-finance.com and will be available again – all the presentations will be available later on this afternoon. And finally, light food and drinks will be served as usual in the lounges upstairs. You're invited to go there following the presentations and Mr. Agon and the Vice Presidents will be meeting you there. Thank you for your attention.
Thank you, Jean Régis. Well, as usual, we are going to begin with Christian who will be presenting the results for 2010.

Good morning to everyone. This presentation of the 2010 financial results of L'Oréal will include information concerning sales, profit, cash flow trend, of course, the balance sheet situation and the dividend growth.

Consolidated sales amounted to €19.496 billion, an increase of 6% at constant exchange rates. Like-for-like, sales increased by 5.6%. The structural effect is slightly positive at 0.4%. It mainly reflects the acquisition of Professional Products distributors in the United States: Maly's Midwest, Marshall, Sullivan and Peel's.

After an exchange effect, which was positive, at plus 5.6%, growth based on reported figures came out at plus 11.6%, i.e., the strongest growth rate in the last 10 years. As far as the exchange effect is concerned, it is difficult to forecast what it will be in 2011. I can tell you however that at current exchange rate that is, for example, with €1 at U.S.$1.36, the effect should be close to nil in 2011.

All the major currencies contributed in 2010 to the positive exchange effect, the U.S. dollar at around 5%, the pound sterling at around 4%, the Chinese yuan at 5.8%, and with a record increase in 2010 the Brazilian real at plus 18.4%. We should note that in 2010 the euro represented 30.7% of overall sales compared with 34.2% of sales in 2009. And five years ago in 2005, the euro represented still almost 40% of overall group sales.

Let us now look at the like-for-like sales growth by branch and division. Professional Products sales increased by 4.1%; Consumer Products sales grew by 5.5%; Luxury Products sales are at plus 7%, a very strong increase compared with 2009; and Active Cosmetics is at plus 4.7%. The Body Shop comes out at minus 1.1% and dermatology, that is, Galderma posted another year of double-digit growth at plus 16.1%.

The results by geographic zones now, all the zones achieved sales growth with Western Europe at plus 1.7%, North America at plus 4.1%, and finally, the so-called New Markets, which posted another year of double-digit growth at plus 11.3%. The New Markets accounted for some 37% of cosmetic sales in 2010 compared with 33% in 2009.

In 2011, the New Markets could become the number one zone for the L'Oréal group's cosmetic branch at current exchange rate. Amongst the New Markets, Asia-Pacific recorded strong growth at plus 11.2%, and growth excluding Japan was even stronger at plus 13.2% and the same applies to Latin America at plus 17.5% and it even rose to plus 32.6% based on reported figures. Of course, we're talking here about the exchange impact. Eastern Europe came out at plus 8.1%, with strong growth in Russia and more contrasting trends in Central Europe. And finally, Africa and the Middle East posted growth of plus 4.1%.

Here is now a close-up of the BRIC countries, which generated a growth rate of around 15%. And three of them have recorded sales of at least €700 million to-date, which means that at L'Oréal, they are close to the size of the major European countries and they are now amongst the top 10 subsidiaries of our subsidiaries. Note the speculator growth of India, which is going from strength to strength at plus 32% like-for-like.

This table is particularly interesting in our view. We're talking here about the sales by business segment. As you can see, L'Oréal is concentrated on five major categories. All of them recorded positive growth in 2010, with particularly strong advances for skin care and make-up. On the last line, you can also see the emergence of deodorants, within the hygiene category, showing a growth rate of plus 15.8%.

Moving on now to the profit and loss account and let us begin by analyzing gross profit. Gross profit increased by 12.1% and came out at 70.8% of sales, compared with 70.5% in 2009. This represents an improvement of 30 basis points, which really corresponds to what we had indicated to you at the end of August, when we said that we were expecting for the full year 2010 a slight improvement of our gross margin.

There are several factors which had a favorable impact. Amongst which and in decreasing order of importance, we have the significant improvement in the cost of goods achieved in particular from the strong growth in volumes and good performances in raw materials and packaging item purchasing. Second factor, better inventory management, which led to a reduction in provisions for obsolete and slow moving inventories. Third element, the reduction in physical distribution costs.

On the other hand, two factors had an unfavorable impact on this item and I quote them also here in decreasing order of significance. First one is the impact of changes in monetary parities. To illustrate this point, the negative impact of the conversion effect alone amounted to 50 basis points over the full year.

To express this more clearly, the 2009 gross profits calculating using the 2010 conversion tables would have come out at 70% and not 70.5% as reported. At constant exchange rates, the improvement in gross profit is therefore very substantial. The second factor which had an unfavorable impact was the moderate increase in customer allowances, which, as you know, are deducted from sales if you apply the IFRS standards. So there is an impact obviously on the gross margin, so much for the gross margin.

Research and development expenses increased by 9.1% and accounted for 3.4% of overall sales. Like-for-like, the R&D expenses, of which three quarters are allocated in the Euro zone increased by 8.9%, that is, more than the sales, which grew by 5.6% like-for-like. This new advance illustrates why the strategic decision was taken to make significant investment in research.

Advertising and promotion expenses came out at 30.9% of overall sales, in line with the indications we gave you when the first half results were published. I would remind you that advertising and promotion expenses are not just media costs. They reflect a variety of realities depending on the divisions and commercial channels concerned. In the Professional Products Division, for example, technical training for hair dressers and salon merchandising. In the Consumer Products Division, we have media and merchandising expenses and point-of-sales initiatives.

In the Luxury Products Division, we have media expenses across the beauty advisers, merchandising and samples. And finally, at Active Cosmetics, it has to do with the cost of medical reps, media expenses and merchandising in pharmacies.

Selling, general and administrative expenses grew significantly less rapidly than sales, at plus 2.7% based on a comparable structure and identical exchange rate, plus 2.7%, which is an increase of 60 basis points compared with 2009. Overall operating profit came out at €3,057 million, an increase of 18.6% representing a significant improvement in profitability compared with 2009, that is plus 90 basis points.

Just a few words about the P&L by half year. As you know, at L'Oréal, the running of the divisions and zones is based on an annual timeframe, and therefore, it is never possible to extrapolate from half year results. However, we can tell you that in the second half of 2010, currency fluctuations had a more negative impact than in the first half of 2010 on gross profit expressed as a percentage of sales.

Here again, we are talking about the conversion effect that I mentioned before, which was really focused on the second half of the year. As with SG&As, they were again improving in the second half of 2010 compared with the second half of 2009, even though the improvement was less spectacular than in the first half of 2010 because of the lower comparison base at the end of 2009. Overall, the second half operating profit also grew very substantially at plus 15.3%, following the first half growth rate at plus 21.4%.

Operating profit of branches and divisions; all the divisions achieved growth in their operating profitability, particularly the Luxury Products Division from 15.1% to 17.5%. Some other points are worth noting, for example, the decline in non-allocated expenses, central costs at 2.8% of sales; the continuing recovery of The Body Shop at 8.7% of overall sales and income, and further improvement in the profitability of Galderma at 19.8%.

Operating profit per geographic zone; all zones recorded an improvement in profitability. Western Europe at 21.6% of overall sales compared with 21% in 2009. Thanks to better organizational efficiency; North America, following the strong rebound at 16.5% compared with 14.5%; and the new markets, which continued with their growth at 16.9% compared with 16.4% in 2009.

From operating profit to net profit excluding non-recurrent items, which is the basis for calculation of our net earning per share. Financial costs have been reduced. The net finance costs fell substantially to €35.6 million. This sharp reduction is mainly the result of the very significant decrease in our net debt.

For 2011, all other things being equal, the finance costs will be close to probably €10 million. Sanofi dividends amounted to €284 million, an increase of 9.1%. Tax amounted to €932 million, representing a rate of 28.2%, slightly above the 2009 rate, which was 27.3%.

For 2011, we can at this stage of the year even though it's still very early on to say anything about this item, we can anticipate a rate in the order of 28%. Once again, all other things being equal, 28% is figure. Net profit, excluding non-recurrent items, came out at €2,371 million, an increase of 18.7%. Net earnings per share, at €4.01, increased by 17.2%.

You can see this on the last line. You should note that the number of shares used for the calculation of the net earning per share at 591 million shares was slightly higher than what had been anticipated. This is partly the result of the exercise of stock options in the second half of 2010, but above all, the result of the IFRS method, which consists in allowing for a theoretical, additional number of shares, which could be created in the future as a result of the possible exercise of stock options.

To illustrate this point, based on the current L'Oréal share price, that is €87 or €88 or €89 and all other things being equal, a diluted average number of shares of between 598 million and 600 million should be taken into account for 2011.

Let us now look at the end of the consolidated profit and loss account after allowing some non-recurrent items, which amounted to a charge, net of tax, of €131 million. Net profit amounted to €2,240 million, an increase of 25%. The non-recurrent items consisted of, first of all, depreciation of intangible assets amounting to €42 million, net. Secondly, provisions, relating to investigations by competition authorities amounting to €79 million. Most of this item was already set aside in the first half of 2010, and finally, some supplementary items for restructuring programs amounting to €8 million net.

Let us look now at the cash flow statement. Cash flow or gross cash flow amounted to €3,171 million, an increase of 15%. In the depreciation, amortization and provisions item in this statement, depreciation and amortization declined slightly from €781 million in 2009 to €768 million in 2010. Provisions, which amounted to a net charge of €53 million in 2009, amounted to a net reversal of €34 million in 2010. The difference, results mainly from the provisions corresponding to the implementation of restructuring costs and the ongoing process of prudently strengthening the financing of our pension funds. There was a very positive change in working capital, as it was reduced in 2010 for the second consecutive year, by €132 million. Inventories increased slightly as a percentage of overall sales. On the other hand, trade accounts receivable improved, once again, this year.

Capital expenditure continued to be contained, at 3.5% of sales for 2011. A slight increase in this percentage may be expected probably to around 4% of sales. After dividend payment and purchases of acquisitions, which I will remind you correspond to the acquisitions of Professional Products distributors in the United States, and allowing for the exercise of options, the residual cash flow comes out at €1,981 million.

The balance sheet now. We have here a balance sheet structure as you can see on the screen now, which is very robust. As shareholders' equity represent 61% of total assets there, increased compared with year end 2009 is the result of the balance between on the positive side profit for the period and the cumulative translation adjustments, because of the positive foreign exchange impact, and on the negative side, the valuation of the Sanofi-Aventis shares and the payment of dividends by L'Oréal.

Moving on to the gearing, the year end 2010 net financial debt comes out as a very small amount €41 million, which is lower than what we were expecting even six months ago, and this is partly because of the further improvement in working capital this year. The net gearing is close to zero, as you can see.

Few words about the dividend, the dividend to be proposed to the Annual General Meeting on the 22nd of April will be €1.80 per share, representing 20% growth compared with 2009. And this increase in the dividend corresponds to a new increase in the pay-out ratio, which comes out now at almost 45% this year, indicating L'Oréal's constant concern to implement a balanced and dynamic policy vis-à-vis shareholders. Thank you for your attention.

Congratulations. Christian, thank you very much. Now as usual, we are going to be presenting to you what generates all these numbers because these figures are the result of all of our action in the area of research, product innovation, launches, conquest campaigns around the world. And we are going to begin with the Consumer Products Division and Jean-Jacques will be telling us about the conquest of 2010.

Good morning to everyone. The Consumer Products Division achieved growth of 5.5% in 2010, after growing by 3.2% in 2009. In the different parts of the world, on this chart, you can see the split of the growth. In Western Europe, where growth is back plus 1.3%, with €3,665 million; in North America, plus 4.7%, and growth has speeded up nicely over the second semester, and €3,698 million, plus 10.7% in the new markets, the zone which became the number one zone of the division in 2010.

Within these new markets, we can note that all the BRIMC countries have shown double-digit growth, all of them, Brazil plus 22.5, Russia plus 10.4, India plus 31.3, Mexico plus 11.4, and China plus 12.3.

And finally, among our top six countries, three are emerging or growth countries, China, Brazil and Russia. In terms of market share, these increases in turnover are translated into market share gains in all regions. You may remember that there was a drop in market share in Western Europe in 2009. In 2010, we stabilized market shares upwards with increases in countries such as the UK, Germany, and Scandinavia, a slight drop in France and in Italy and a more significant drop in Portugal and Greece. With gains on important categories such as make-up, haircare, deodorants, and a slight drop on styling and colourants. So as you see, there are differences across Western Europe, but the overall result is good in a market with the growth rate next to zero.

In the U.S., in a market estimated at plus 1.2%, our sales have grown by 5.6%, so that is to say more than four times the market, with strong gains in make-up, colourants, and haircare and a slight drop in skincare. In the new markets, our growth is also superior to the market, in particular, in Asia, Latin America, and the Middle East.

Our three brands show growth; L'Oréal Paris plus 2.8%, Garnier plus 5.7%, Maybelline 13.3%. There are two significant highlights for L'Oréal Paris, the launch of Youth Code in Europe. The U.S. are launching at the moment and here's the film.
[Video Presentation]

And the shampoo Elsève, collagen Elvive hydrated curls collagen for curly hair, for which you can see the press advertising. And Garnier, the extension of deodorants with Mineral for Men in Eastern Europe, and Pure Active, which has allowed us to take first place in Europe in the care for problem with skin markets. Here's the film for the Pure Active Exfo-Brusher.
[Video Presentation]

The top prize goes to Maybelline. The growth of 13.2% is probably the largest growth of any Consumer Products brand worldwide and merits a special focus on the brand and the market. The make-up market is one of the markets, which has best resisted the economic crisis. Our broader studies and our psychological experts have shown the anti-luminous effect of make-up and the need to feel good and take care of one's look even in times of crisis. The most dynamic categories over the last two years have been foundation and eye make-up. At the same time, the fashion is for color, the nail polish market is exploding, and lipstick is making a comeback, all of this is shown into the figures.

In the U.S., the market has grown by 5% versus the total beauty market of 1.2% and in Europe by 3.5% versus the total market showing zero growth. In the new markets, it is one of the most dynamic sectors. Our nail polishes in Latin America are at plus 40% for the year. Maybelline has launched innovations in all categories. Here is the advertising for SuperStay 24 Hr Lip Color, one of the most significant innovations.
[Video Presentation]

In Asia, the big phenomenon is the BB Cream, already a star product in Japan and Taiwan and in China. This is the product that does everything, half skincare, half make-up, it protects from the sun, hydrates, tightens up pores, covers imperfections, serves as a base for make-up etcetera. Here is one of the Chinese films.
[Video Presentation]
Probably, the most interesting point is that the product introduces new consumers to the use of make-up and allows us to develop the market.

So to conclude on make-up which I remind you is the number one category for the Consumer Products Division, with the market shares of Maybelline and L'Oréal Paris combining to give us closer to 30% of the market worldwide. We are not only undisputedly number one, but also the only company to have worldwide brands which are capable of seizing the opportunities that arise in all corners of the planet. For example, this Lasting Drama gel eyeliner invented in Japan and sold all over the world.

I will now take a more detailed look at the emerging country. First of all the growth, I have spoken about the growth in the five biggest countries. In the column to the right are five others which are also showing strong growth, where our brands are establishing themselves and which are the growth areas of the future. In the Middle East, we are moving forward with Garnier. In the Philippines and Indonesia, we have launched L'Oréal shampoo.

Now for the product, in order to gain a billion additional customers – consumers, we are of course launching our major brands or international ideas, but now we are also inventing products in these countries, which can then be marketed internationally.

The case of Total Repair 5, which was the key, which allowed us to open the door to L'Oréal shampoo in India, and in South East Asia, which was invented in Brazil. The Garnier Mineral deodorants, which were invented for the Russian market and which are now available in India, South Africa and Western Europe.

And finally Garnier Men, which was invented in India and is now sold into rest of Asia. This will be the case more-and-more often. Thanks to our knowledge of consumer needs and our local development laboratory, which will enable us to create new products.

Along with this, we now have an industrial savoir-faire that allows us to produce our products in the excessibly priced formats requested across all categories by our consumers in these countries and aiming to gradually reach 1 billion additional consumers.
Here you can see three sachets that contain between two and five applications of product. Of course we are going to continue along this track in 2011 and do better in several areas.
Here are our objectives for 2011. Continue to launch innovative products; renew our attack on the markets with L'Oréal Paris, we want to more than double growth versus 2010 for L'Oréal Paris.
And you will see in future advertisements, a new breath of creativity, which shows that more than ever the number one beauty brand in the world is desirable and up-to-date.
Thirdly, we wish to develop our categories across all our target groups, men, seniors, young people.
Fourthly, gaining market share in Western Europe by successfully executing points one, two and there.
Five, continue the geographic expansion of our brand. And lastly maintain our stand on business drivers.

Now as a preview of 2011, L'Oréal Paris make-up will launch this fantastic new mascara Lash Architect 4D. The results of our research and development in Japan and the fibres in mascara have allowed us to produce the best mascara that L'Oréal Paris has ever made and here's the film.
[Video Presentation]
And the Infallible foundation with brush applicator, its gives incomparably uniform coverage. Alongside EverPure and EverStrong in the U.S., L'Oréal Paris is launching the EverSleek range.

I remind you that these products sold at $7 are an important dominization of the haircare market. And everywhere the colorant mousse, Sublime mousse, a very interesting step forward in terms of ease of application.
For men there is the latest launch from L'Oréal Men Expert the Gel. Garnier will have a strong start to 2011 with a new initiative in body care Intensive Seven Day Replenishing Lotion with Bifidus.
Maybelline will launch a new foundation range FIT ME, and a new Volum' Express One by One mascara for which I want to show you the film.
[Video Presentation]

And finally, in order to take advantage of the massive growth of this very profitable market, we're launching on to the mass market, the SE range of professional nail varnishes that we bought in 2010. So we are extremely confident that our innovations, our brand and the strength of our teams will allow us to achieve a very successful year 2011.
Thank you very much, Jean-Jacques.

That sounds – that's really fascinating. We're now going to go to a very different world, the world of luxury and I'll hand over to Marc, Marc Menesguen will be telling us about the luxury division in 2010. Over to you.

Good morning to everyone. 2010 marked a return to growth for the Luxury Products Division on every continent. The Luxury segment is back. As we had sensed a year ago, the Luxury beauty market bounced back in 2010, with according to our estimates consumer sales up plus 5.5%. In this resurgent market, our division consolidated its global market shares with like-for-like growth of 7% and published growth of 11.5%.

Broken down into publication regions growth stood at plus 1.9% in Western Europe, with consumer sales in line with the market. We remained the market leader and we have boosted our market share across Europe to almost 20%, way ahead of our nearest competitor. Plus 4.5% in North America, we made the most of the recovery in this part of the world, although our consumer sales are slightly below the market baseline.

Lastly, we grew by more than 14.9% in the new market. These strategic countries which already account for almost 20% of our turnover are becoming increasingly open to Luxury product. And we have reinforced our position as the number one in these markets.
In Asia, we are growing one and half times faster than the competition with excellent results in Korea, Hong Kong and China, where we are the market leaders with a 27% market share.

In Eastern Europe, we are progressing fast in a market that remain very stable. We are now gaining ground on the competition in the region as is the case in the Middle East where sales are – have risen steadily.
Lastly, L'Oréal's Luxury product posted strong financial results for 2010. Our operating income gained 250 basis points, plus 25% on the like-for-like basis and reached 17.5% of turnover.

2010 is also a pivotal year for our brand and a year in which our portfolio strategy was clarified. Our three key brands, Lancôme, Giorgio Armani and Yves Saint Laurent accounted for 60% of our business. These three prestigious global and multi-segment brands are gaining ground and modernizing.
For Lancôme, the world's number one luxury brand, synonymous with femininity in every country of the world. 2010 was a year of renewal as illustrated by its strong worldwide growth of plus 8%.
Lancôme found a new spark of magic in 2010. Thanks to the beauty and sensitivity of some exceptional women, three great actresses, Julia Roberts, Kate Winslet and Penélope Cruz.

Lancôme has also confirmed its position as an innovation leader with significant progress made in the area of skincare. Thanks to the success of Génifique. The first skincare product based on generic signs, which has doubled its sales in only second year of existence.
The brand success was also done to increase sales of its key Luxury skincare product Absolue Precious Cells a combination of 20 years of stem cell research; its success has been global.

Another major event was the launch by Lancôme, the world's number one seductive make-up brand of Teint Miracle, a revolutionary formula that recreates the skin's inner light. Since its launch, Teint Miracle has already become number one in France, Italy and Germany and has recently received the prestigious Marie-Claire Prix d'Excellence award.

And to celebrate its 20th year, Trésor is being launched afresh with a new advertising campaign. The irresistible charm of Penelope Cruz pushed sales of our legendary perfume to new levels, capping off a great year for Lancôme.

Yves Saint Laurent, our haute couture brand epitomizing French audacity and elegance, 2010 marked something of a renaissance with two figure global growth. Thanks mainly to the new found vitality of its women's perfumes. The brand reinvented the legendary Opium perfume to create Belle d'Opium, a modern oriental embodied by a mesmerizing Melanie Thierry. But also thanks to the dramatic return of Saint Laurent's fetish color with the launch of Rouge Pur Couture, the color of heroines, a potent weapon of seduction that joins other iconic stalwarts such as Touche Éclat and Volume Effet Faux Cils Mascara.

The global growth potential of Yves Saint Laurent make-up is considerable. The brand is also highly attractive to men as demonstrated by the rise in sales of L'Homme et La Nuit de L'Homme fragrances in 2010. I am convinced that Yves Saint Laurent will one day become one of the five top brands in the world as it already is the case in France.

Giorgio Armani, our high Luxury brand inspired by Italy's great designer, 2010 was a year of growth driven by a winning strategy. Our main priority was to reinforce investments in the two historical cornerstones of the brand, Acqua di Gio and Code Homme; the number one and number three men's perfumes in the world, respectively. These fragrances seem to have limitless appeal. We also launched the new women's perfume Acqua di Gioia or Essence of Joy, the portrait of a striking and modern women and an initiatory voyage into sublime nature. It is already Armani's bestselling brand perfume and was one of the perfumery sector's great success within 2010.

Lastly 2010 saw the rapid rise of Giorgio Armani Beauty carried by the success of Rouge d'Armani, a jewel of current sophistication. And the Eyes to Kill mascara as embodied by the stunning Megan Fox, who is now the face of the brand.

Another asset of the brand's beauty range is skincare with the launch of Regenessence, a highly innovative anti-ageing product, inspired by regenerative medicine. As you can see the Giorgio Armani brand is better equipped than ever to conquer the world.

2010 was also a crucial year for Kiehl's, the New Year's modern apothecary. Kiehl's has become a major global brand, and it is now present in 37 countries. It experienced tremendous sales growth in 2010 around the world at plus 43%. Kiehl's is driven by strong values when it comes to performance, but also in terms of sustainable development and commitment to social issues as illustrated by the charity campaign run in collaboration with Jeff Koons.

The success of Kiehl's is done to highly original skincare product, such as the new Midnight Recovery Concentrate, and Night Elixir that is extremely pleasant to apply and very effective, a unique brand experience in stores, unprallelled customer care and first-class service that appeal to men and women from all over the world.

Also 2010 will be remembered for the dazzling launch of Kiehl's in Asia. In Korea, it's an incredible success. The brand has already number one in its 29 department stores, ahead of all the global brands. And we also hope for in Japan as well as in China, where Kiehl's is already one of the most successful brand at its 11 point-of-sale with wonderful potential for development in this country. Today, Kiehl's is present in just 750 point-of-sale around the world and both exceptional turnover per outlet. So the Kiehl's saga is only just beginning.

Lastly, I would like to highlight the dynamism of two more of the division's strategic brands. Shu Uemura, first of all the Japanese Art of Beauty, a Tokyo based brand is a major asset in our conquest of Asia, its sales are up by 17% due to the success of pioneering and highly innovative product such as the make-up removal oil and the UV base Foundation Primer but also thanks to its typical Japanese quality of service.

And Ralph Lauren, the brand started by America's great fashion designer. They also had good momentum in 2010 with the launch of Big Pony, a collection of four men's perfumes that perpetuate the great tradition of the brand and express the Ralph Lauren Lifestyle in its purest form, it's a great success both in the United States but also in Latin America and throughout the world.

The division's brands are therefore firing on all cylinders and are more aspiration more than ever. Now we also have , we transferred the Roger & Gallet in the to the Active Cosmetics division of the group with our 10 biggest brands so representing 95% of our turnover. We have the most beautiful portfolio of brands in the profession and we have wonderful development potential on every continent. 2010 was also a year of the increase in two areas, key for the future of the group.

First of all, in the digital department, we – Lancôme was the first luxury brand at – who have a presence on the iAd. The iAd, which is the brand new interactive advertising platform on Apple's mobile application. So another example is on YouTube. Just before Christmas, five of our brands were promoted in spectacular fashion on the homepage. There were 360 million pages viewed in just five days and this indeed demonstrates the power of this medium. Our brand is also very much involved in ecommerce with an increase of 30% of our turnover in 2010.

In terms of distribution in retail, there are two events that need to be highlighted. First of all we opened some exclusive brand stores, especially Kiehl's stores to have presence of our brands in high traffic areas which are not covered by our partners and distributors.

We also strengthened our leadership in Travel Retail which is a highly dynamic channel that represented in itself a market the size of United States and serves as a fantastic shop window for luxury products. We are the historic leaders. We are pioneers and we are the historic leaders in this high potential channel which draws high income clients from all over the world. And in 2010, our brands grew by 22% in this segment.

In conclusion, as you can see, the luxury products division has completely transformed itself and is now well equipped to take full advantage of the tremendous opportunities like Luxury is going to be offering in the coming years all around the world. I am now transferring this division to Nicolas Hieronimus who I am sure will be able to take the division to its new heights. Thank you very much for your attention. Thank you. Thank you very much.
It is now Nicolas who will be telling us about his former division, the Professional Products division which also had a great year 2010.

Yes indeed, good morning. For the Professional Products division, 2010 was an excellent year marked by a strong gain in market share on a channel of moderate growth and marked by the conquest of a record number of salons, thanks to our successful initiatives and the complementarity of the our brand portfolio.

In 2010, the global salon market for professional products grew at an estimated plus 1.3%. It was strong in growth regions like Asia, excluding Japan, Latin America and the Middle East and it was stable or with a slight recovery in mature countries. In this contest, the L'Oréal product – Professional Products division generated a sales growth of plus 4.1% like-for-like, a performance that is above the market in every region of the world.

On reported figures, growth was plus 13.8%. So this was a great year of conquest allowing us to increase our estimated market share to 28% and to enhance our worldwide leadership, which is today very significant.

In Western Europe there are slightly positive global markets, if we exclude Greece. Our annual sales growth was plus 2.2% with significant gains of market shares in Germany, Great Britain, Sweden and France.

The conquest of more than 4,500 salons such as the going to our market share gain. In North America in a salon market of 2% growth we achieved plus 2.5% with as a highlighting performance of L'Oréal professional. The brand become a significant player in the market thanks to Inoa, which was a hit from a – among American journalist and she is going to be able to do that in American salons where alongside Inoa, which is off to a great start. Our American brands, Redken and Matrix, which are number one and number two in the market are confirming their leadership.

Regarding our salon-centric distribution network, we were able to complete an ideal territorial coverage through several acquisitions of regional distributors. Maly's Midwest and Marshall at the very beginning of the year followed by CB Sullivan and Peel's in December.

In new markets, the division grew by plus 8.6%. The three main regions are dynamic Latin America at plus 13.2% with very strong results in Brazil; Africa, Middle-East at plus 13.3%, and Asia, excluding Japan at 15.6% with India, China, South Korea and Indonesia acting as drivers of growth.

Overall, it's interesting to note that all – of the top ten countries contributing to our growth, there are five mature countries and five new markets. The divisions determination to reaffirm its role as leader and to act as the industry champion has enabled us to again gain one market share point by innovating for hairstylists with – hair style and with hairstylists and by taking numerous initiatives to boost the market. Innovation for and with hair style experts, which resulted in a big year for technical products, which is to say those used by professionals for services in their salons. These products are essential to our growth because they consolidate our commercial relations with the salon professionals.

Hair stylist is one of our typical and remains a loyal customer for a very long time. And of course that's the slide says what we did with Inoa hair color, which was deployed rapidly worldwide basically in Brazil and China. And it's an exclusive salon technology in well over 81,000 salons, 40% of which did not previously use L'Oréal products. And they show a very high satisfaction rating. In the hair color, there is also a Matrix and with its new 90ml of SoColor Beauty format that offers hair stylists the most affordable price per application of any leading international brands. There's Redken with color fusion and the strong growth of our hair color applications demonstrate that – this is says of this multi-brand strategy.

Other technical and professional products include products for texture in a worldwide development of the Brazilian hair straightening treatments; include the success of Moisturist, by L'Oréal Professional artist trade in India. And last but not least, there is also fiberceutic and its Intra-Cylane by L'Oréal professional and Chronologiste by Kérastase.

In 2011, we will continue to innovating products for technical services and real term products with Inoa supreme based on ODS technology dedicated to mature hair Redken to come down hair thinning and hair loss. Kérastase' Elixir Ultimé launched in November and already a success. And also the first cleansing balm Chroma Sensitive or Matrix with its accessible line of hair care Total Eesults.
In addition to innovation, a leader must also stimulate its market and help hairstylists to attract more women more often to their salons by talking directly to women by advertising.

The Inoa multichannel approach with the digital print and TV campaign and reception for a professional product has brought several thousands of women into salons, which have displayed the communication campaign in their windows. So putting this channel also means encouraging hair stylists to reinvent their hair salons. This is what we did with the concept salons presented with the toolbox to be implemented at the inaudible] Beauté event. They have already inspired a lot of salon professionals. Giving hair service, all the keys for success is also what we will do with salonworld.com. This first multi-brand portal will offer professionals other solutions to their needs with inspiration, training and partnership or just simply connection to their community.

The division has digital at the heart of its strategy of growth. Building our future means of course boosting new markets by educating and inspiring future generations of hair stylists. The L'Oréal Professional Institute opened in June in Rio will train this year 1000 students in hairdressing, who will be our future customers. The concept would be deployed in a number of Brazilian cities with a target of 45,000 students per year.

In March 2011, we will organize an International Symposium of French on Perfume in China attended 3000 Asian hairstylists, and Asian entrepreneurs in search of inspiration. It's a premiere in this country, where expect to reach out to the new generations of salon professionals and thus make a huge step forward with our division. This determination to be beyond just a leader also the champion of the exciting business of professional beauty has helped us win over more than 35,000 additional salons this year and gain one market share point.

So today, I am very pleased and proud to handover the legacy of a wining division, a division with the portfolio of eight brands well-positioned to cover the entire market through both their inspiration and price level.

A division with breakthrough innovation and skills that paves the way for the future of hairdressing has become the leader of the profession numerically but also in terms of heart and soul. And I'm convinced that within the health centers heading the division, we will inexorably strengthen our leadership in this market. Thank you.

Thank you, Nicolas and congratulation. There is a division which is not changing, Brigitte, it was here last year and again this year and you're going to be able to tell us about last year and your vision for next year.

Good morning to everyone. We were optimistic last year and we were right. In 2010, we got back on to a growth curve. The Active Cosmetic division increased turnover by 4.7% on a well dermocosmetic market with estimated growth of 2.5 and this was like-for-like. And the good news is that every brand and every zone without any exception is expanding.

The first satisfaction is that Western Europe is 3.1% up. The main driver is La Roche-Posay which continues its growth. The United States continued upward trend with an increase of 4.5%. A large number of doctors have opened the skinceuticals account and La Roche-Posay increasing present in American drug stores.

Finally, we are pleased to announce an acceleration in new markets up by 7.7%. The expansion of the dermocosmetic market worldwide will continue over the coming years for three main reasons. Firstly, the whole world is looking for health in beauty. The middle-classes in the emerging countries as well. They are in search of tested and proven formula on sensitive skin. They want reliable products, recommended by dermatologists. They are also increasingly concerned by prevention and global well-being.

For example in Brazil, more than one woman out of two, claims to have sensitive skin, it's the same proportion as in the United States. In China, 37% of women complain of allergic or intolerant skin and this is same proportion as in France. Second reason, the pharmacy has clearly become the preferred channel for skin, health and beauty concerns and the same applies all over the world.
In Brazil for example, skincare sold in pharmacies represents more than 50% of the total market and the expansion of modern drug store chains in Asia is a real opportunity for all of us.
Finally, dermatology is taking shape and evolving towards aesthetics everywhere in the world. Cosmetics are being increasingly used to complement drug prescription.

In 2010, we confirmed our position as the world leader in dermocosmetics. Here are the four drivers behind this leadership innovation, partnerships with health professionals, adaption to local needs and a unique brand portfolio.

The first innovation, our policy has given good results with the successful launches of anti-aging skincare Neovadiol and LiftActiv by Vichy as well as Redermic[+], La Roche-Posay. This has reaffirmed our number one position in anti-aging in Western Europe.
We've also launched a new filter system, some filter system, MEXOPLEX, which represents a major advanced in sun protection.
Let me give you another example of innovation. The entry price product ranges such as Essentielles and Vichy price at less than €10 or La Roche-Posay.
Looking back one year, we can confirm that we've recruited new customers, attracted by products which combine the benefits of simplicity and the reliability of the pharmacy, particularly in Europe.
The second driver behind our leadership is our partnership with pharmacists and dermatologists. We strengthened these links even more in 2010, thanks to increased training of pharmacy staff.

We have also increased the number of doctors visited by more than 20% in every geographical zone, mainly regarding La Roche-Posay and Innéov, adapting to local needs. This is the major source of our 19% growth in Latin America.

We have formulated our products to meet local expectations. The Anthelios sun care product has a fluid texture to correspond to humid climate. With Vichy we've developed Normaderm soap bars for greasy skin, a recurrent problem in this region. And the soap is produces locally.

This leads us to our fourth driver, our unique and more than ever complementary brand portfolio, which enables us to cover every consumer expectation in health and beauty. The reigning champion in this area is La Roche-Posay. The brand is recommended by more than 25,000 dermatologists across the world and continues its double-digit growth, four times more than market growth, gaining over 9,000 new point of sale in 2010.

Vichy, the number one dermocosmetic brand has achieved great success in the Anti-Age segment in every zone, particularly in Asia, and in Hygiene in Western Europe. And we also have our other dynamic expanding brands contributing to overall turnover.

Today, they account for more than 20% of Active Cosmetics growth. They have opened more than 10,000 new pharmacies. They complete our care range from the organic segment with Sanoflore to the super-sophisticated segment with SkinCeuticals by our nutricosmetics through Innéov or the perfume refreshing models of Roger & Gallet which join our division, as Marc said, last year and is already experiencing more than 20% growth in Western Europe.

2011 will be rewarding a year in terms of new initiatives for all of these brands. And the pride of place is for Vichy. We are launching LiftActive Derm Source after 10 years of research, seven patterns, six scientific publications and seven clinical trials.

LiftActive Derm Source is a revolution in anti-aging. It is really wonderful, and we're in the process of launching it now. La Roche-Posay is satisfying the needs of a fast-growing market, ultra-sensitive and allergic skin types. Tolériane Ultra contains an ultra soothing ingredient without any preservatives and presented in the tightly sealed pack.

It is worth noting that according to the World Health Organization in 2012 in the industrialized countries, one out of two individuals will be affected by allergies. At the end of the year, we'll be launching Innéov onto the Chinese market, which already represent as much as the whole of Western Europe in nutricosmetics.

We also intend to reinforce our links with Asia. The L'Oréal Group will be the main sponsor of the World Dermatology Congress in Seoul in May 2011 will be an opportunity for our brands to establish even closer links with dermatologists.

As you can see, we are approaching 2011 with maximum optimism. We have full confidence in our ability to continue to create and develop health and beauty products as the cutting-edge of innovation right across the world. I thank you for your attention.

Good morning. I think that these presentations are very useful or in any case I hope so. They enable you to understand what is behind the numbers, and better understand the job of each of the divisions. L'Oréal is beauty, but each division has an expertise and a method which is very complementary and specific. And we are the only beauty group – global beauty group which is active in all these four areas.

I would now like to make some comments about what I considered to be the most important aspects of our sales and our performance in 2010 and share with you, as usual, my vision of our strategic prospects and our major opportunities for the coming years.

First of all, the markets, I imagine you're interested in that. After proving resilient in 2008 and 2009 during the crises, the world cosmetics market returned to growth in 2010 with an increase that we estimate at 4%, in line with the forecast we made at the same meeting one year ago. The market has thus returned to a growth level, which is close to its historic rate, as you can see.

As could be expected, there have, however, been short contrast in growth rates between the different geographic zones. In Western Europe, it's slightly positive market at plus 0.7% in a difficult environment, as you know, in North America, a clear upturn in the market with growth in the order of plus 2.4%. And Japan a slightly positive market at plus 1.3%. And once again, it is the very strong growth of the new markets in the order of 8.7% which is driving the global market.

But there are some fairly considerable differences and situations across the geographic zones this year. Strong growth come back in Latin America at plus 13%, good growth in Asia Pacific at plus 9% and more moderate growth in the two other regions because of difficulties in certain countries, Africa, Middle East with a growth of 5.7%; only in Eastern Europe with a growth of 4.7%.

Other distribution channels achieved a positive growth and the market was particularly driven by the upturn in Luxury. Over the last three years, the cosmetics market has thus demonstrated its considerable resilience during the crisis and a strong rebound potential after the crisis.

We believe that the momentum will continue in 2011. And in our estimates the market may once again grow by between 3% and 4%, with a growth rate that is once again high in the new markets. And probably a confirmation of the upturn in North America and we hope a slight growth increase in Western Europe.

In the medium and long term, we are very confident about the sustainable development potential of the cosmetics market whose growth, global growth, may even accelerate because of the increasingly important weight of the new markets in which the emergence of the middle-class is boosting the consumption of beauty products.

In 2010, growth at L'Oréal also rebounded well, as it amounted to 5.6% like-for-like, reflecting the way the group has outperformed the trend in world markets as a whole. Growth based on reported figures at 11.6% is spectacular because of an extremely positive exchange rate effect reflecting, in particular, the strengthening of the currencies in the new markets, which enabled us to achieve this record sale figure.

And this performance is both solid and global, because it has been achieved across all divisions and all geographic zones. At division level, the Consumer Products division which is the group's largest last year continued as you have seen to win market shares worldwide, thanks to the power of Express, L'Oréal Paris, Garnier and Maybelline and thanks also to the quality of its international and regional adaptations. Obviously, the consumer products division will be the spearhead of our conquest of a further billion new customers over the coming years.

The Luxury Products division has returned to a good level of growth, at plus 7%. It has reinforced the power of its major brands with Lancôme, of course, and the acceleration of Yves Saint Laurent and Armani and you have seen the extraordinary success of Kiehl's with growth at 43%.

As for the Professional Products division, its true level of performance goes well beyond the 4% growth recorded in a market which was still depressed. It was the big winner in its industry, thanks to the international success of Innéov. And thanks also to the record number of new salons recruited and the major advances made in penetrating strategic markets of the future such as China, Brazil and India.
As Brigitte indicated, Active Cosmetics bolstered its position as the world leader in dermal cosmetics with La Roche-Posay and and Roger .

The Body Shop had a more difficult year, but we believe it was a year of transition, which enabled it to complete its strategic organization and improve its profitability. It has stepped up its policy of ethically based innovations, accelerated its move into new markets such as in India, where the brand has doubled its store base and extended its distribution to include new channels such as the Internet and travel retail. We believe the brand is now ready to return to like-for-like sales growth as early as 2011.
Lastly, Galderma had an exceptional year with double-digit growth in amounts invoiced and once again made market share gains.

In geographical terms, the three zones saw their growth accelerate compared with last year, as you saw in the press release. In Western Europe, the group's growth was in line with the market, slightly above the market, with performances that were good in major countries such as the UK, France and Germany; and less good in Southern countries affected by economic difficulties.

In North America, L'Oréal clearly reinforced its positions in mass market segments with very significant market shares gains. The same applies to professional products where our network of distributors strengthens the power of our brands. In the Luxury segment, our growth was below the market trend.

Finally in the new countries, the group sales increased quite as fast as the cosmetics market. In Asia, growth amounted to 13.2%, excluding Japan, and spectacular advances in India and also in Indonesia, Philippines and South Korea. And our growth remained strong in China, despite temporary difficulties in registering new products which affected the whole of the industry.

Latin America had an excellent year at 17.5%, thanks to remarkable performance by Brazil at 21%, and also Argentina, Mexico and Chile going south. The growth rate slowed in Eastern Europe, particularly in the Central European countries which have been hit by a difficult economic situation, as you know. But our growth has remained strong in Russia with market share gains across all divisions.

Finally, in Africa, Middle East, we have been held back by temporary difficulties in South Africa, but we are growing fast elsewhere and growth in this region should rebound in 2011. Overall, in 2010 the group has strengthened its positions worldwide and made decisive breakthroughs in the new strategic markets for the future.

So 2010 was a year of conquest during which the group made the most of the new strategic thrusts adopted at the end of 2008, which I would now like to run through. The first was concentrating on major global innovations with high value-added but accessible prices.

We have successfully continued in 2010 and will continue in 2011 and beyond, our trading right strategy. This strategy of offering innovation without devaluing the products enables us to reach more consumers. INOA, for example, is used in more than 81,000 salons worldwide as Nicolas indicated. Of which 20% were not previously L'Oréal professional customers.

Over more than 5 million units of Génifique have been sold since its launch, it has been an excellent recruitment product for Lancôme. Maybelline has reported double-digit volume growth. And Essentielles and Vichy has also won over new pharmacy customers. We are thus widening our customer base.

The second major strategic thrust in 2008, which was applied in 2009 and '10, is the extension of our brand to cover new product categories, such as men's skin-care and deodorants in order – once again to enlarge our consumer base and generate to growth which is purely additional.

With the launch of Garnier Men in India and then in most of the Asian countries, our two major consumer products brands now have a men's line. Both are proving highly successful, particularly in Asian countries where there growth is the most spectacular – men have no taboo regarding skin care.

And we have captured first place in this market, which is developing and growing very fast, in particular, in China, where we have become the leaders in men's skin-care. At world levels of sales of the division in this category has grown by 22%.

As for deodorants, that is a huge market. This is a category in which we are still quite small. We have only just started and in which we have a great deal of development potential over the coming years. 20, 25 years ago, L'Oréal had also started new products, skin care or makeup and that carried the group's growth for many, many years.

The third strategic thrust is the accelerated globalization of our brands. We have strengthened, as you've seen, the penetration of our brands, which were already present to the new markets. Matrix is now present in more than 60,000 salons in the BRIC countries. And we have expanded the distribution of Garnier to more than 400,000 outlets in India.

We're launching our relay brands in new countries as is the case of Kiehl's, which is moving into India and is proving highly successful in China where it was launched last year. The brand, we've accelerated our rollout in new countries such as Egypt, why not? Pakistan and Kazakhstan.

And during 2011, we will be opening new subsidiaries in Saudi Arabia and Nigeria and the areas where we do not have a base or – very small one. In 2010, we achieved a major milestone with our Chinese subsidiary which passed a €1 billion sales mark and has become our number three market worldwide.

As Christian indicated in 2011, for the first time, the new markets may be the group's number one zone for sales. Maybe because it depends on the euro and its value and depending on the months and depending on the market, but the new markets zone may become the group's number one zone, ahead of Western Europe and North America.

For the first months of the year, we made about 40% of our sales there and objective is to make between 50% and 60% of our sales there in the next year depending of course on currency fluctuations. So weight of the zone is advancing inexorably, and this will have a mechanical effect accelerating the group's growth.

Finally, the fourth strategic thrust was increasing our spending on research and innovation, and on advertising and promotional resources. The research budgets grew by 9.1% in 2010, reflecting clearly our determination to boost our investments in this key sector.

Although blockbusters from our laboratories are proving to be genuine worldwide success stories. We – the cosmetics is essentially technological and we are convinced that it is through research and innovation that we will stand out from the competition, and we will continue to reinforce our global leadership.

Our advertising and promotional expenses have also grown significantly by 11.9% with gains of share points in strategic markets, such as the U.S. and Brazil. We are going to intensify our efforts to improve the productivity of these advertising and promotional resources, which is one of the first tasks to be tackled by the newly created strategic marketing division to optimize return on investment in this field.

We've also had a good year as you've seen in terms of results. I am not going to repeat what Christian said in his presentation of course; but I think that these results show that the company is moving forward and adapting to change. All the actions taken in the field of operational excellence over the last two years to improve the company's performance and make it more responsive are continuing to pay-off.

Just a few examples, 2010 was a record year in terms of industrial productivity. Our global program to improve the efficiency of our facilities has enabled us to gain close to 10 points of productivity in three years, representing a capacity gain of 20% using existing facilities. 2010 was also a record year in purchasing terms.

The grouping together of purchasing into four sourcing centers and the specialization of lead buyers on a global scale to build coordinated purchasing strategies worldwide are opening up new pathways to progress in conjunction with our suppliers.

The modernization of the company is also reflected in the improvement in SG&A. As you've seen there has been a significant increase in terms of the percentage. And this is the overall result of the constant process of optimization of our organizational structures and strict cost control.
It is important to note that all of these advances have been implemented and obtained throughout the company, in other words, in all four divisions and across all geographic zones.

As you have seen the four divisions have different business segments, but they now produce consistent profitability. And as regards the geographic zone, it is important to point out the increase in the profitability of the new markets, which has risen in five years from 13.5% to 16.9%, even exceeding the figures in North America, the growth that we are generating there is increasingly profitable.
The good balance between profitability levels, different business segments and regions is one of the group's assets. And it's a major advantage for sustainable and profitable growth.

Overall, in 2010 we have returned to our virtuous circle model like-for-like sales which grew by 5.6%, gross profit rose by 6.7%, research by 8.9%, advertising and promotional expenses by 6%, selling, general and administrative expenses by 2.7% and operating profit grew by 13.5%.

As you've also seen this model is also a strong generator of cash flow, which reached a new record level of €2,625 million. A strongly positive operating momentum means that we can look forward to the future with great confidence in the middle and the longer-term. And we're therefore proposing a significant increase in the dividend to the tune of plus 20% at €1.80. And as regards to the future, precisely I would like to share with you our strategic prospects.

In fact, the world today is facing three major upheavals which are at the same time three significant opportunities for us. The first major upheaval is the economic and demographic change taking place in the world. As we all know now, the emerging countries have become vast reservoirs of new consumers. And this trend is set to become even more pronounced.

In 2020, the middle classes – that the middle classes are at the core of our brands. These middle classes in these countries will total some 2.7 billion people compared with 1 billion in 2010. Today western consumers account for some two-thirds of middle class spending worldwide. In 20 years time, probably 70% of the spending will come from the middle classes of Asia, Latin America or Africa.

By then, the world's population will probably have increased by 25% and the number of consumers with access to cosmetics products would have grown probably again by around 50%. And this is because one fundamental needs have been met. Per capita consumption grows exponentially. These countries where per capita consumption is still 10 times lower than in developed countries are just taking their first steps in modern cosmetics. This profound transformation of the beauty market offers opportunities on the scale we have never experienced before. And this is the basis for our objective of winning a further billion new consumers.

Today L'Oréal makes the bulk of its sales with less than 15% of the population of our planet. As you can see on this animated map representing the world of L'Oréal consumers in the different regions, the center of gravity of our consumers will migrate over the coming years, profoundly transforming the configuration of our customer base.

In 10 years time, we should have as many customers in Asia Pacific as in Europe and the United States taken together. As you can see on this map, the Asian continent driven by China and India should be the largest contributor of new consumers. But the major developed markets such as the United States, the United Kingdom or Germany, will also be sources of strategic growth. For, even if our market shares there are high, our penetration surprisingly is still limited and this is fairly interesting idea.

We have identified the fact that our brands for example still only reach one American citizen out of two and one German individual out of three. So we could look for new consumers and we could do this right here, and right now. There's a lot of potential, not compromise. Our penetration of these markets will be increased by expansions into new product categories and the accessible innovation strategy that we have already spoken about.

In addition to this, we have also, of course, identified 15 major growth markets where our positions are still extremely limited today after the brink, we have the next 15 growth markets that we need to look into, but where there is enormous potential. Everywhere as you can see, our horizon is being enlarged in every direction, setting an objective of 2 billion consumers is a considerable change in scale compared to 1 billion today. Considerable change in the ambition for the group, but it is also a perfectly realistic objective that we can reach.

Our company is now in a truly new phase of its history. I'm convinced about this. It's a key phase, which is the phase of so called universalization. In accomplishment of the fundamental mission that we set for ourselves, which is as you know, to offer all women and all men the world of best of cosmetics in terms of quality, efficacy and safety, purpose being to meet all their needs and beauty aspirations in their infinite diversity. The major strategic choices made over the last few years and the deep transformations undertaken in 2010 have prepared the group for this new phase of expansion.

The second major upheaval in today's world is of course the digital revolution. This is a very interesting revolution, because it is profoundly transforming the relationship between our brands and our consumers.

First, because in cosmetics, as you can imagine, the imaginative dimension is very important and the internet enables communications formats which are practically no limits, which are richer and more effective than the short format of television.

Secondly, because in our businesses, promoting new rituals involves expert advice and the internet certainly facilitates this approach. Finally, the comfort of service, which is inherent in our business, becomes particularly significant on the internet. Thanks to the possible customization of personalization of contacts and the high-degree of interactivity with consumers. It is therefore an excellent opportunity for our brand – for cosmetics in general and for L'Oreal in particular and for our brands to create new richer areas of expression and more direct, closer, and more personalized relationships with consumers. It is of course a new distribution channel, and therefore a major opportunity for additional sales.

Our brands moved into digital media at a very early stage and we clearly stepped up our efforts in 2010. 2010 was the digital year at L'Oreal, we increased the budgets allocated to these new media, particularly, of course in countries where the internet is already very powerful, such as China, where 8% of – all of our advertising spending is already allocated for this purpose, and we also developed expert advice and personal relations with consumers.

We continue to create e-commerce site for our brands in China, for example we have opened a site which markets all of our luxury brands available in the country. The creation of the new strategic marketing division, again, will accelerate this trend, since the division's mission is to ensure L'Oreal's leadership in the digital media, and to intensify our initiatives and develop our expertise in this field.

Finally, I would say to be complete that the third major upheaval in the world is the change in societies and citizens expectations about major companies. L'Oreal is the world's leader in the business of beauty, but L'Oreal also intends to be an exemplary corporate citizen in all fields of sustainable development. And sustainable development for example through our pioneering advances in the field of product eco-design, green chemistry and our worldwide leadership in predictive methods and environmental methods through our extremely strong resolve to reduce by half within 10 years our production it CO2, our water consumption and our waste generation.

In ethical behaviors and diversity through our ambition to be one of the companies most widely recognize around the world by its achievement in these areas. And finally, in terms of similarity by the development of our initiatives to benefit local communities in the areas of which we operate particularly through the L'Oréal foundation, after all the actions we have undertaken over recent years. All these efforts meant that L'Oréal once again was ranked in 2010 as one of the 100 most sustainable and ethical companies worldwide. And this will make a decisive contribution in the future to the group success and to reinforce in its leadership.

But as you can see L'Oréal is particularly well adapted and prepared to tackle the challenges of the world – currently being transformed and indeed to make the most of them as major strategic opportunities. I'm fully convinced personally that these specific and intrinsic strengths of L'Oréal give us unique advantages in achieving success in the new world emerging today.

What are these key assets? Concentration on a single business segment, which is beauty. Passion for research, innovation and creativity, the culture of excellence and quality, a very strong corporate culture and the exceptional degree of commitment of our employees to which maybe added the power of our brands and our totally global reach.

I wish to, second, pay tribute to Sir Lindsay Owen-Jones, who was both as you know the architect and the builder of this magnificent company which L'Oréal has become today. He chaired over the company for 24 years with immense success. As announced yesterday Lindsay Owen-Jones will be stepping down as the Chairman of the Board on the 17th of March, which is the date of his 65th Birthday. As he had always intended and he had announced and he will become Honorary Chairman of the L'Oreal company. From that date onwards, I will therefore have the dual role of Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, and I measure the degree of the honor and the responsibility which will be mine but I put a trust in the future of the company.

I am convinced that L'Oreal is moving towards the new phase of its history to the phase of universalization of beauty, as I said. And there is this major objective, which is beauty for all. This is indeed a very important objective that we have to win an additional billion of new consumers. This conquest would motivate each of us and drive the group's growth for the long-term.

This conquest will indeed drive the group's worth. For the next 20 years, it will be solid, sustainable and profitable growth. And as far as 2011 is concerned, which is the beginning of the next two decades and I am sure that you will have questions on that obviously, I could tell you as of now that we are encouraged by very sound beginning of the year. It's very encouraging we feel and we trust in the capacity of the group this year to once again outperform the cosmetics market, strengthen its global positions and deliver yet another year of growth of its sales and profit.
Thank you for your attention.
Thank you and you deserve a short break, not too longer break if you want us to have time for questions.
So, let's go. Who would like to ask the first question? Eva?

I have two questions, the first on the market growth. You mentioned 4% since the beginning of last year. I'd like to know whether the growth was balanced during the course of the year or whether it has slowed down. And I'd like to see how you see the consumers developing – will it be a consumer pulled by value or innovation for next year?
And for Mr. Lebel, how do you see the L'Oréal brand did outperformed in a dynamic market. Is it a matter of communication or how can you address these problems in the long-term?

Well, that's a nice for a start. Well, first of all, I must say that personally I'm rather pleased with the forecast we made for the market. If I'm not mistaking, these past two to three years, we always announced at the beginning of the year a market forecast which turned out to be correct, with last year that the market would be at around 4% and our most recent estimate is 4%. And frankly speaking, we have not seen – we did not see a change in the pace of the markets during the course of the year.

And regarding invoicing, because I'm sure, your question – next question will be why was the fourth quarter lower than the third. It's more related to launches or big American clients that reduce their inventory at a point in time, and this is not due to a significant drop in consumption. So consumption was fairly homogenous during the course of the whole year 2010.

And it may be a little early to make a commitment. But it would appear that we have the same basic trend for 2011. We believe that 2011 will be a repetition of 2010 for the basic trend. As I indicated earlier, consumption will be fairly flat or slightly positive in Western Europe. One cannot exclude having a good surprise in North America. There could be good news.

And on a contrary, we are convinced that consumption in all the new markets will be good, and here also there may be some volatility. The economic evolution of the world is not of smooth sailing and doesn't happen equally in all countries. Eastern Europe last year was a little more difficult, some Asian countries progressed more quickly. So, we are confident at the group level that the market will progress in 2011 and we are confident that we can outperform the market.

So, L'Oréal Paris brand. Well it's a good question. The L'Oréal Paris brand had a growth at 2.8% and there was a higher growth for Garnier and Maybelline. But last year L'Oréal Paris had a growth of 0.7%. So, there is an improvement and we plan to double it this year and increase it from 2.8% to 5.6%.

Why do we believe in that? We have several reasons to do so. Last year, we got rid of a few obstacles to the growth of the L'Oréal Paris brand. We had no entry price products. We now launched the Triple Active product line, which are at an entry price, which the consumers needed. Same for mascaras, we have a cascading to also have a product at an entry price. So, we solved that topic without reducing the prices of the product.

Now regarding communication, there had been perhaps a bit of where a certain repetitivity of our L'Oréal messages, I don't know whether you saw the most recent ads. There is a new breath, a new way of speaking to women and these films are really liked in all the countries where they have been shown and sales have been increasing for L'Oréal Paris, for skincare and make-up. So, we are very confident.
You have also seen that we're launching the L'Oréal Paris brand in a country such as India, where we have had Garnier only for 10 years. So we're launching L'Oréal Paris in India and it's doing well.

So, the idea of having the mass premium and the extra quality is very attractive. And more than ever the quality signals which are conveyed by the L'Oréal Paris brand and the "You're Worth It" slogan are all part of that.

And there is also the development of the Men Expert brand. It's the number one brand for men in Eastern Europe and China also. And we hope to develop it a lot. We've added deodorants and coloring products, men's hair coloring products, which have started very well in 2010, and which here I hope for development in the men's customer segment for next year.

Going back to the first part of your question, we're also very confident on the ability to bring added value. I don't think that the cosmetics market is doomed to having the prices decrease. And the strategic revaluation we did two years ago, affordable or trading right, accessible innovation, trading right is to bring innovation but at the right price, which optimizes both on volume and value. Next question?

Hello, . I have two questions. You mentioned the digital revolution; could you tell us what your exact plans are? Is it just advertising or will you be selling Luxury products on the internet for instance? Now regarding your shareholder shift, the settling of the dispute within the Bettencourt family, has that given rise to some concern amongst the shareholders? And then there is the problem of Nestlé. Are you aware of Nestlé's plans regarding their stake in L'Oréal and if yes, that's of course a problem.

Well, I'll begin with the second question. I don't have any new news on that.
