And what I usually answer this question – to this question which I hear very often is that during the past 30 years, we've had a stable shareholder shift and that was an excellent thing for everyone, for the company, for the shareholders for Nestlé for the Bettencourt family, and all the other shareholders. And at this stage, I have no additional information that would lead me to answer otherwise.

Regarding the digital revolution, we believe that digital will be a revolution mostly in terms of communication with the consumer in our line of business. It will be a revolution in terms of communication. And on the three aspects, which I mentioned the communication of our image service, counseling and also thirdly the individual element and in a business such as cosmetics, it is a true revolution.

Last year, with the Heads of Division who are present here, we asked all of the brands to make a determined commitment in the area of this digital revolution to see how each of these lines could best use the digital technology. And there are a lot of projects underway. And Jean-Jacques example for – for example in the area of e-commerce.

Perhaps I can ask the camera to focus on my iPad. Here you go to the Apple Store, here you download the Club des Créateurs de Beauté application. And you have their digital catalog, 50% of our Club des Créateurs de Beauté orders are done via internet. And so you can turn the pages of the catalog. And you can select your products in this very modern way.

If I go to my favorite product, which is here the Agnès BB Cream, the first BB Cream to be available in Europe. I can click on that and add it to my shopping cart. So, this has been available for one month on the iPad. And women who access the Club des Créateurs de Beauté via the iPad buy more than the average customer.
What about Luxury?

Well, we have some experience of the e-commerce in the Luxury division. We had an online site for Lancôme in the U.S. As I indicated in my presentation, e-commerce and Luxury has progressed by 30%. It accounts for about 2% of our global sales. But in certain countries such as the U.S. it's already about 6%, in Korea over 10%. And for certain brands, young brands, in particular such as Kiehl's, globally we're already at 10%. So, it's an interesting sales channel. And very complementary to our traditional store channel. A question in the second room.

Hello. Daniela Fernandes da Costa from Valor Econômico from Brazil. I'd like to know, what process the Brazilian market offers for the near future and the longer-term future? And in which sector of activity will you be strengthening your development in Brazil, and for what reasons or for what in the short term?

Thank you for your question. Brazil is a very strategic country for L'Oréal. As we've indicated earlier, it has become one of the biggest countries for us. We sold for €700 million there and with that pace of growth it will soon be one of the top countries in terms of sales for the country, which is normal since it is the third cosmetic market globally on an equal footing with China.

So, our strategy is very clear. We wish to maximize. It's the third market on a par with China, well ahead of France and Germany, et cetera. So, our strategy is clear. We wish to maximize our presence. We are very present in Brazil in the hair products and in coloring products and we will continue to develop our presence. We also have an interesting presence in sun protection products and our intention is to increase our presence in the mass market progressively in the skincare products and make-up. And alongside that the Professional Products division is very present also. Nicolas, do you want to say a word there?

The progress was achieved by An Verhulst-Santos when she was head of Brazil. Well Brazil is an example for us. It's still in the top two or three contributors of the growth of the division for a few years, is a number six country. I think it will move to fifth position next year. We have 25% market shares in Brazil and the Brazilian consumers very much like the services that we talked about earlier, the hair straightening and coloring. We wish to reach 30% of the market share in Brazil. we have great ambitions for Brazil which should become one of the top countries for the group. We may perhaps go back to the other room?

Yes, my friends. I will ask my question in English. You have been focusing on developing markets, but there are quite a few challenges there and distribution system being one of them. So, my question to you is, what do you identify as key challenges in these markets and how do you intend to overcome them?

That's a very broad question, because there are many, many different situation. No, what we see, in fact is generally speaking, we are able to identify the challenges and find the solutions. I mean and it's true that whether it's truly a question is that all markets are different. You don't conquer China like you do for Brazil or Russia or Indonesia, but we are very pragmatic and in every country in every situation we try to define the right business model, the right strategy, the right approach to find the solutions.

So we don't see, honestly today especially in terms of distribution, we don't see any major difficulty. The only sometime think that that slowing us down is the fact that in some countries there is not enough stores. For example, if you think about India, we would like to have in India more supermarkets, hypermarkets, department stores, perfumaries, et cetera. That will help, for example, the development of a division like the Luxury Division. But besides that we are very pragmatic and we adjust ourselves to the situation of every country. So we don't see any major hurdle on our development there. I don't hear you anymore.
Sorry.
Would you consider an acquisition to lead you to growth in these markets. I mean, you've been talking about growth in -

I know that everybody is very excited about the acquisitions ideas. But to answer precisely, we don't need acquisitions to speed up the growth or the conquest of these markets. I mean, we have today – I think it's a very important point to understand is that – it's a very interesting idea. In fact, international brands are really extremely appreciated by consumers in the new markets, some time even more than their local brands. So for us today to grow fast in all these new markets, India, China, Brazil, Indonesia, Philippines, everywhere, we don't need a new brand, a local brand. In fact we can really conquer the markets with the international brand that we have. So, if we consider one day an acquisition, it would be for a very specific purpose, but it is not needed for our development there. Okay? Thank you.

Bonjour, Crédit Mutuel-CIC. I have three questions. First of all, on China, please. Could you give us an update on the position of the Chinese authorities, plus 25% in 2009, plus 11% in 2010, where do you put the cursor for China in 2011? So for consumer products, could you tell us who are the winners and the losers compared with your competitors per major category of product for the year 2010?

Third question; could you come back to the Luxury products and the fact that in the U.S. your performance was lower than that of the market? You talked about the phasing of some of new launches, but in the end it wasn't exactly what you were expecting. So, what do you plan for 2011?

Well, we will try and answer this quickly. There are many questions. First of all for China, we had said last year that the growth pace would probably be a little lower due to the regulatory problems we encounter as does everyone else in the country. This is what happened. Things are improving progressively, not quite as quickly as we would hope, but things are improving. And in 2011, we do hope to reaccelerate our growth on the Chinese market. You also need to know that we're having good sales, over €1 billion, but our ambition is to continue to reaccelerate our growth on the Chinese market.
Regarding consumer products, I'll ask for an update from Jean-Jacques, but we will not be telling you about our competitors; that would not be elegant. Jean-Jacques Lebel?

Well, for make-up, for instance, we are the winners and in all geographical zones; Eastern Europe, Western Europe, North America, Japan. We also won market shares in Japan with Maybelline. Our position there is very competitive. And so for make-up, we are the great winners, globally. There is another category where we are the great winners in the areas where we have operations is in the hair care. We are the great winners and we are penetrating the Asian market. We're penetrating the market, but we're still very small.

If you take other categories, we have other competitors who are European competitors, which may have scored some points for hair coloring in Europe in 2010. There's not much more that I should say, because, otherwise, I would have to give names.
In total, consumer products had a good year 2010 and rather better than its competitors. That's the main point.

And as you have seen, some of our competitors are moving out of some categories, which is a good sign for us. Luxury in the U.S., well, as I said and as Jean-Paul (sic) [Jean-Jacques] indicated, our consumer sales in the U.S. were a little under the market. I'd like to say two things, the growth of our consumer sales increased in the second half compared to the first. We won four growth points during the second half – percentage points compared with the previous semester.

Lancôme is still under the market. But it is true that our Lancôme launch plan in the U.S. was not at the same time as the rest of the world time-wise. And the other relay brands performed well. Saint-Laurent had a year at 12%; Kiehl's at 20%, Ralph Lauren with the success of The Big Pony Collection outperformed its market in fragrances, Acqua di Gioia was very successful in the U.S. So a clear success, so we're very confident for the future.
There is a question at the back and then we'll go to the second room.

Audrey from the Reuters Agency. I have a question. Would L'Oréal consider penetrating direct sales market through an acquisition possibly? And I have an add on question. What do you think about the business model of direct sales?

We've already talked about this during the coffee break. So I'll give you the exact same answer as previously. It is not on the agenda, but we have no taboo. So you can conclude from that what you wish to conclude. I am sorry, I can't say more that that.
We have a question in the second room.

Yes. Good morning. I come from the Herald Tribune. Could you say a few words about the fact that Mr. Owen-Jones is leaving and what about his role, what has he done for the company, especially regarding international sales? Do you know that he was going to leave a long time ago? And is he leaving because of the Bettencourt case? And what exactly is he going to do in the future? What would be his future goal for the company – in the company?

Well, we have issued a press release, which was very specific in that regard, yesterday. And it says very specifically, Sir Lindsay Owen-Jones had always indicated and publically indicated during the shareholder's meeting in 2005, that it was his desire, a strong desire to finish – to finalize the smooth transition of his position on the 65th birthday. He will turn 65 on March 17th and the board of directors met yesterday. He is sticking to his promise. And this is something that he had always planned to do.

Now regarding his future role in the company, I think that we all know what kind of role he will play. Over the last 25 years, he played a very significant role, because as I mentioned earlier, he was the great architect and the great builder of international success of the L'Oréal company. For the last four years or five years Lindsay Owen-Jones was the Non-Executive Chairman of the Board. And as of the 17th of March, Lindsay Owen-Jones will be the Honorary Chairman of the L'Oréal Board, which is a purely honorary role.

He will not play an operational role. He will not have anything to do with the governance of the company. For quite some time, he will remain the Chairman of the L'Oréal Foundation. Can't see you on the screen, so I don't know whether you're satisfied with the answer. He would be board member, obviously, a board director of L'Oréal.

Can I just ask a question first of all on gross margin? Perhaps, Christian, you mentioned the FX impact on the gross margin in 2010. Can you give us any indication on what that might be? A number would be great, but directionally would still be helpful for 2011.

The second thing on the balance sheet, you mentioned that there's very little debt there. And I heard you say this afternoon that acquisitions aren't needed at least in emerging markets. Can you give us some idea, you've got the business back to growth now, after a few years of transition, are you starting to think about how you might be able to use the balance sheet, either through cash returns or are acquisitions still a preference for you?

Yes, as far as the income impact of currency is concerned, it was slightly negative as you know – significantly negative I would say in 2010 as a gross margin. The negative impact of the translation effect was minus 50 – between 50 and 60 basis points, difficult to predict what it will be in 2011. As I mentioned in my presentation, based on the present currency rates the impact should be zero on the turnover, which means that the impact should be close to zero on the result and on the gross margin. Then we'll see.

And regarding acquisitions, there are not indispensable, they are not needed. But any acquisition that would help us boosting our development for every brand or in any part of the world would be very good for the company. And that's why we need a very robust balance sheet in order to be ready for any type of acquisition, plus a very dynamic policy in term of dividends as you know.
Okay. I think there was a question in the other room. Sorry, this one here. We'll take this one and then we'll go to the other room. Please go ahead.

Guillaume Delmas from Nomura. I have two questions. One on the Luxury Division. I was rather surprised to see a shrinking of the margin on the second half, especially because of the good organic growth of the Division and because of the expected synergy from the Yves Saint Laurent business. Could you shed some light on this matter, and can you tell us where you stand with the cost synergy coming from the acquisition of Yves Saint Laurent Beauté? And the second question, just in a nutshell on Maybelline, do you think you will have a double-digit growth figure for 2011?
Maybelline, first of all, Jean, could you say a few words about that?

We always celebrate a double-digit growth years. It's something that is exceptional. We haven't recorded one for quite number of years. I think that the makeup market is very buoyant market. We have a lot of range of wonderful innovations in this segment. And as I said previously with our two leading global brands, the only really global brands, reach with the products all over the world. We have a good chance of making it. For L'Oréal Paris and Maybelline makeup ranges, I think that we can achieve this double digit growth the next year.

Yeah, Jean-Jacques is right, there are business segments which face fierce competition, but I think that for makeup, we have a high potential here. This brand together with L'Oréal Paris is the only truly global makeup brand, which has a footing in all countries, and the innovation is coming from all over the world and that can be made available to all consumers in the world. I think that this is a strong engine. It is not by chance that Maybelline had a double digit growth last year. And I'm sure that we'll do everything we can to make it happen again this year.
Marc, not Jean-Jacques, Marc will answer this.

Yes, let me answer on the Saint Laurent part. Regarding the acquisition of Saint Laurent, it's all happening very smoothly. We are exactly on track when it comes to our business plans. Saint Laurent was profitable in 2010. The synergy that we recorded following the pooling of the support functions and the industrial reorganization and the synergy that we achieved in purchasing, looking at all the sources of synergy, all of this was beyond our expectations. And as Jean-Paul said from the beginning, we have negotiation to – we have a strategy to develop the brand. So, we're ready to invest a lot in our brand, and we're very happy to see that the brand is speeding up and accelerating very strongly, because as you know, as I said, we had a double-digit growth with this brand, with beautiful results in France and Germany and Italy, but also in the United States, for example. So, we are very satisfied with the integration of Yves Saint Laurent from a human organizational standpoint. Also, it's all happening very smoothly. We are doing well. And this is of course very good for the entire portfolio of brands in the division.

There was a question regarding the margins of the second half compared to the first half. That's not the way we manage our business. That's not the way we do things. We have different margins per division on an annual basis. And of course then you can compare between the two halves, but it all depends on when the launches take place or the time chosen for the investment. So, this is not something that you can extrapolate from.

As Marc said earlier on, the major element is that the Luxury division has really rebuilt its profitability very significantly in 2010, over an additional 250 basis points this year. And I'd like to point out to you that compare to our competitors this level of profitability is much higher than theirs. So, I don't think we have any problem when it comes to the profitability on the Luxury Products. Any further question?

Simon Marshall-Lockyer from Jefferies in London. I have two questions. The first one is on Inoa in the United States. You launched the range in April of last year. Could you give us an indication regarding the number of salons, the trend, the momentum that you've created for Inoa in the United States at this stage? Second question for Christian Mulliez, regarding the raw materials, maybe you did mention the price of raw materials, but I wasn't around. On raw materials, do you have a target or do you have an estimate for 2011 regarding the cost of raw materials? And could you give us an indication of what kind of impact it will have if we had an oil barrel around $100, could that have a significant impact?
Nicolas, could you tell us about Inoa in the United States, it's a beautiful adventure.

Nicolas Hieronimus. Yes, there was a national roll-out of Inoa as of the month of April of this year and as you saw, we did very well, we are in 4,000 salons in the United States, 3,800 to be precise that's the latest figure. 40% of these salons did not work with L'Oréal Professionnel products before. So, we are really talking about a fully fledged innovation and we have strengthened the presence of L'Oréal Professionnel products. It was a challenge around American market and we – this was a beautiful adventure and we are only just beginning.

You're right. It's quite an important turn in history, in the United States. We've managed to acquire the leading brands; Redken and Matrix. So, we are leading the market by far, but the development of L'Oréal Professionnel products is fairly difficult and the launching of Inoa is indeed the historic opportunity we were waiting for in order to assert the presence of L'Oréal Professionnel brand and we will not miss this opportunity. Regarding raw material, Christian?

Yes, regarding the possible increase of input costs, in 2010 as you've rightfully noted, there was a positive impact on our business and this contributed significantly to the improvement in the cost of goods results. For 2011, we have a number of financial assumptions, which we have not made available, but they are fairly cautious. And I think we have a good illustration of this and we could give you an example on the screen. You will see it anytime now. I have to speak slowly while they're looking for the slide.

Here it is. You can see illustration on the slide, yes, that slide, but there was another one, I was thinking on. You can see for packaging, the basis of 100 in 2005. Then you can see the impact of the increase in raw materials and plastic or derivatives. We should have had 113 in 2010, but now it's a 96, so that's the impact and the same goes for raw materials. We could have shown you another statement under the table, which is the oil content in a bottle. But the oil content is very low. So we are not really sensitive to do these kinds of impacts.

Jean-Paul Agon talked about this in his presentation. We also have programs for concentrating our purchasing worldwide for centralizing the purchasing. We have a suppliers' panel that has been opened to other geographic areas, including Asia and we are very confident that if there was to be a negative impact on the input cost, it should be limited and well under control. I think it's important we should note this.

You'd been able to see here and there that some companies were indeed concerned by the increase in raw materials or input costs in 2011, but we are not overly worried, especially because our products are products with very low value added. So, the price of the input costs do not play very major role in our overall prices. And also, we are completely revamping our purchasing strategy, globalization, concentration, re-negotiations are the key words of this strategy. And we should be in a position in 2011 to have a positive effect that would make up for potential increases in input costs. It is our ambition to continue to improve our gross margin. So, we have no major concerns regarding input costs.
Emmanuel? We need a microphone for this gentleman.

Good morning. Some points of clarification, first, that you need to give us or ask us about, I've a list here. First of all, what about the weight of emerging markets and new markets for Body Shop? You said that the trend was accelerating. Secondly, I saw that Sanofi was offering to pay out its dividends as shares. Now since it is consolidated in your financial statements, I wanted to make sure that you would continue to pay out your dividends in cash. Could you also have the relative weights of the three major brands in the Consumer Products Division? And last technical question. I'd like to check why the margin went down in the Professional Products Division in the second half? Was this due to the acquisition of distributors, which happened during that semester? So, these are the small questions and I've then more basic issues that I would like to ask about.
You should have asked with the basic questions to Mr. Agon. Christian, could you take as many questions as you possibly can?

Yes. Perfectly normal. For Sanofi you will not be surprised. We will see – we will – Sanofi announced that in principal they will pay out the dividend as shares, but didn't how they're willing to go about this. We'll look into this. We really have the lot of Sanofi shares in our portfolio, don't we? Regarding what you said about The Body Shop, we're doing this in a rather informal way, but talking about The Body Shop – absolutely, we have to give you the results like-for-like. Regarding emerging markets, emerging markets account for 46% – 45%, 46% of overall sales for the Body Shop. And it is interesting to note that The Body Shop is only just starting in India with some 20 stores and for the last year or so. So, there will be a lot of expansion planned. The Body Shop at this stage does not exist in China and The Body Shop does not exist in Brazil either. So, we have a lot of potential for The Body Shop, considerable.
Between 45%, 46% in emerging markets, is that what you said?
Yes. If you take all of the countries, it's 45% to 46% in emerging countries. What was the question to Jean-Jacques and Mr. Agon?
The weight of the three brands in Consumer Products.

We have the three major brands which account for 92% of overall sales for the Group. There was another question, what was it? The gross margin increased a lot because of the mix effects and the hair colorant segment regarding variation from one half to the other. It's not significant. It all depends on the balance between the brands and between the different products category, depending on what brands we pushed in the second half. It doesn't mean that there will be any major change. It wasn't linked to the acquisition; they were all concentrated in one half of the year.

So fundamental question. Only one to Jean-Paul Agon and to give time for the others. Well, regarding the use of cash, you still have quite a few Sanofi shares. So presumably you are not without cash. You no longer have debt. Now, do you exclude the possibility of a buyback of shares and basically do you feel the need that you build up a stash?

Well, I'll answer that simply, as Christian indicated, our priority in the allocation of cash is for acquisitions, acquisitions, acquisitions and more acquisitions. Number two, there is one interesting concept. The major companies around the world are often companies that are cash rich. So perhaps these days having positive cash situation is not necessarily a problem. And at this stage we have no decision regarding a resumption of share buyback. So, thank you Emmanuel.

Hello. Pierre Lamelin from Cheuvreux. First question, could you give us the traditional table for the growth between value and volume for makeup – sorry, for cosmetics? And secondly, we haven't heard about the Diesel brand for some time. So, how is it doing? And what is the limit for the payout ratio?

That was clever on your part. We have never presented the table for volume and value, nice try, as you say. So Christian could tell you about the effect, there is a slight positive value effect. Now while Christian is getting ready, Marc, can you just tell us about the Diesel brand?

Well, yes indeed, we did not mention the Diesel brand. In 2010, Diesel grew at a pace which was just under our average growth. But the Diesel brand remains very strategic for the division. It's a recruitment brand. It is a brand for recruitment of men and women to the fragrance market. And the two pillars that we launched during these past years are Only the Brave and Fuel for Life. They have settled well into several markets; France, Germany, the UK. And we plan a very strong launch plan for this year for 2011. And I'm sure that the brand will continue to progress and recruit new customers. What about volume and value, Christian?

Well, for sales up 5.6%, the volume effect is just about 5%, so the value effect is 0.5%. A positive volume effect in all the divisions, very positive for Consumer Products, that is no surprise. We're in line with what we had said for the half year results. And for value, a very positive value effect for Professional Products and slightly positive for Luxury and the two other divisions. Consumer Products very slightly negative, and Active Cosmetics is practically at zero, so, so much for volume and value.
We have a question from the room next door. You sir, you have the floor.

Zuanic, Liberum Capital. Just I want to ask a few mathematical questions for Christian, and then if I may follow-up for Jean-Paul. First, Christian, the question was asked before that the growth rate for the market was above 4% for the full year, but the growth rate of L'Oréal slowed down as a year progressed. So, does that mean that the company's ability to gain share slowed as the year moved ahead? That's the first question. The second question, last year, if I am not wrong, you did give guidance that EBIT margins would be up for the year. Are you going to give guidance this year? So far you're just saying, sales growth and EBIT growth, but no comments on margins, if you can comment on that? And the third point -
May I just answer your second question and you will keep the mic for the third question okay?
Okay.

So, for the second question we are not ready to give precise guidance, but Jean-Paul Agon said that we anticipate the market growth worldwide, which should be between 3% and 4%. And we expect to outperform the market once again this year, because that's what we can say today here in February. We'll see later in the year if we can be more precise. In term of profit, we will not give any precise guidance on our profit, but we can tell you today that we expect an improvement in the EBIT as a percentage of sales.
All right.

Regarding the first question maybe, again I said before during the meeting that you should not extrapolate anything of the fourth quarter of 2010. What we have seen in the fourth quarter is that the sell out of our products was generally good. Then the quarters in term of sales of shipments are sometimes volatile. And this should not – this should not extrapolate anything on the following quarters. And that's – and we believe that the fourth quarter of 2011 will be okay.
Okay. And if I can just follow-up on one last – one mathematical for you Christian and then I will come back to Jean-Paul. I am very much -
Okay, mathematician.
Yes.
But just one more please, because after that we have other candidates here in the room.

Okay. I mean, I always think of the 7 – the 8% growth rate that you posted in 2007. And if I'm not wrong, your underlying market growth year was about 5%. So you were able to grow about 3 points above the market. Once the market recovered, is that the type of growth rate that L'Oréal should aspire to? And I say that because, based on everything you have explained, I'm quite convinced that the company structurally is in much better shape than it was three years ago. So its ability to gain share, should be better.

Now if I may, just a last follow-up for your Jean-Paul then on the strategic front. Estilo they are, I am sorry to talk about the competition, talks a lot about the high-touch services that they are providing in the department store channel in the U.S. And although I don't necessarily, I'm not a consumer to those products, I don't see necessary L'Oréal offering the same type of delivery, if I can use that word, at the department stores that Estilo would be doing.

And also you know hair care, it's a category that for L'Oréal has been, has lagged in terms of growth if I look at your slides, and I'm not talking about color, I am talking about hair care, and obviously Unilever made an acquisition there. So just strategically, what can we expect about hair care going forward, if you can comment in terms of your services or versus high-touch Estilo and department stores in the U.S. And then just last point for Christian on that growth of 2007? Thank you.

Maybe I will take Christian's question, because it's not that mathematical. It's more a question – it's more strategic, but first, thank you very much for your comment, because I totally agree with you that we also believe that L'Oréal is perfectly equipped in term of brands, products, R&D, innovations and teams to over perform – to outperform the market and gain market share and that's absolutely what we intend to do in 2011 and in the years to come. It's – some years you can outperform in a major way to market and some other years you outperform maybe a bit less. But our ambition – you're perfectly right and I'm totally agree with you is to outperform the market and we think that we have everything in order to do it. That's what we're going to try to do again in 2011.
Regarding the remarks of Mr. Frieda said for Estilo there, maybe Marc can tell you where.

I think these remark of Mr. Frieda is, Luxury is about service is one-to-one and we have been investing a lot also on quality of the service in point of sales in the U.S. One of the key reasons of the – the amazing service of Kiehl's, for example, is an amazing quality of service. So it's really very, very high-touch service.

Also I can underline the very good performances of our brands in Asia and also we know that everywhere in China – everywhere in Asia quality of services is paramount importance in the success of brands, and we're doing very well in Asia. So I agree with Mr. Frieda we're doing also a lot to raise the quality of our service in point of sale everywhere in the world.

But we have nothing to be ashamed off. I mean, our Luxury division is very strong. It did well by the way in 2010. The plus 7% was a good number. We grew our market shares in many regions of the world. We are very strong in Europe. We are growing very fast in the rest of the world. So we are very, very committed and very confident about the future success of our Luxury division. Jean-Jacques, hair care.

Yes, on hair care, I could not agree with your numbers or the way you view the market. We have a good growth in hair care. Actually it's the category that grows the best after color cosmetics. We had growth in market shares in the U.S. this year and the year where there was a major competitive relaunch by a big competitor. We have a market share growth in Europe and we're penetrating Asian markets like India and China and Indonesia and so gaining share in those parts of the world as well. So both in terms of our sales and in terms of market share hair care is a good category for us.
Okay, one for Christian
Fine for the questions, Shamina, perhaps.

Shamina Bhaidjy, Natixis. I have several questions to the two of you. You each get questions. Concerning the working capital requirements, Christian, can you help us a bit for 2011? How do you see that heading evolving, you mentioned a slight increase in the inventory?

Well, I thought I was going to help you. Last year when I said that the working capital requirement were decreased by a little over 100 million and a decrease by about 300 million. So this confirms, it's a very difficult line to master. And so I would like to renew for 2011 repeat that the needs will be growing. It will be a need for working capital requirements. Part of the improvement comes from the supplier heading and it is not a deterioration in the quality of payments by L'Oréal. It is the pacing of purchases during the course of the year, and it will not be renewed in the same way this year compared with last.
So, we have if – every reason to believe that our working capital requirement will be, well let's say, 100 million to 200 million, so much for that.

The second question is the operational margin per zone. There was a strong increase in North America in 2010, and the growth was much lower in the new markets. I assume that this is due to the development phase, which is implementing itself. Could you tell us the prospects with the new markets, and what your expectations are for the top line? How do we see things evolving on margins for the other zones apart from Western Europe?

Well, the thing you must look at is, Mr. Agon, is that the profitability in North America has recovered in 2010. It's not so much that it has progressed so much more than the new markets, it has recovered. It had been higher. It had dropped during the crisis. It had strongly impacted North America as you all know. And it's the same thing as for luxury division. It's a great come back. It's a great recovery on the – for profitability for North America. So things are not comparable. What is interesting is that the new markets zone has seen its profitability increasing regularly, which is encouraging. It shows – it proves that the growth that we are generating there is a profitable growth, and it will continue to grow. We're not going to give you guidance on the profitability per zone this year. But our ambition is to enable it to progress progressively in all three regions.
Is the benchmark of Western Europe, the objective for the other two regions? Can it be reached structurally?
Well, it's not a good benchmark, because it has this very specific characteristic due to the Group's structure. Maybe, Christian can explain.

Well, the margins ex-Europe for Luxury and active cosmetics are integrated in the profitability of Western Europe. Economically, it should be reallocated to the internal client, the North America new market zones. So that part is purely technical. As far as the rest is concerned, there is no reason why China, which has exceeded Germany, Brazil and Russia, could be exceeding other large European countries. There is no reason why they could not reach very high profitabilities. They are today at very high profitability. Otherwise the new market zone would not have profitability at 16.9% which is 80% of, or 90% of what it is in Europe.

One very last question. You mentioned a good start for the year 2011. Could you be a little more specific? And my question will be even more specific. Do you see a change in trend per zone? There is a fear of slowing down in the emerging countries. Have you seen a trend per zone?

Don't say some things that I didn't say. I said that the beginning of year was encouraging. I said this because here or there one has read concerns expressed by some people regarding the fact that 2011 would be more difficult than the year 2010 and this is not what we believe.

We believe that 2011 as far as the market is concerned. It's looking more or less the way that previous year was looking, as far as the possibilities of outperforming the market or we are beginning the year with the same prospects as last year. So there is no reason, why we should do less well.
And thirdly, we don't see – to answer your question, we are not seeing any major change in the consumption patterns, including in the new market zone.

As I was saying earlier, you must understand that the new market zone is an area, which includes – let's say 5 billion inhabitance or something like that. So it's not how much you need. What we are saying is that we are seeing a tremendous boom in Latin America and we are determined to take advantage of that. So Latin America is accelerating compared with its historic pace – growth pace of the past.

We are seeing a good pace in Asia and China is continuing and Africa and the Middle East we are also seeing growth continuing and in Eastern Europe, we are seeing some amount of difficulty. It is no secret that there are number of Central European countries, which are seeing difficulties.
But all-in-all when you add this all up globally, it remains very dynamic, very positive as is the global economy.
So we as far as we're concerned are very confident for the year 2011 in terms of market share gains, in terms of growth and growth of our results because our prospects seem good.

Capital markets, I have two questions. Do you think that the price mix effect could accelerate this year given the present context? And also you were talking about optimization of the return on investment on your advertising and promotion investments. Could you tell us a little more about that, how can you track the return on investment in that area and what are your objectives in that area?

Well, I begin with the return on investment and ask Jean-Jacq, as the Consumer Products division which is the most advanced – the monitoring of the return on investment of A&P investments. There are two slides which more or less illustrate what we do. The first is that, we – the most important thing is our ability to negotiate good purchasing contracts for our advertising media. So we put into question, media we buy with – we reexamine the pitches. We believe that we have the best buying conditions around the world.

To give you an idea that price of media – the price increase in 2010 compared with 2009 and it has gone down a lot then because of the crisis. And I think we were able to gain €50 million in media efficiency compared with a strict comparison with inflation. Now, next thing on the next slide is that in four major European countries, we have setup a modeling system with the best firms consultancy firms and they are able to model from all the sell-through data and the media and promotions. The effect of each Ad campaign in a very precise way and we're going to continue that this year, we're adding a . And at the end of the year, we're going to be choosing one or two methods which would – which we're going to be working in the future.

But we are already getting very interesting indications on the way to optimize sales . It's not a matter of spending less; it's a matter of spending it in the best way during the course of the year, et cetera. And we've invested in digital as we said, but we're putting ourselves ahead, we're progressing with the encouragement given by Jean-Paul Agon and Marc Menesguen.

There is one Asian country where we already have evidence that with an exclusively digital campaign, it's a campaign for which there was no other form of advertising, it was only digital advertising, we became number one for a category of product for a specific period. So, we already know how to use digital to gain market shares and increase sales.

We're very ambitious and confident regarding our ability to optimize these investments, which are very important, says Jean-Paul Agon. We believe that it is an area of improvement for the years to come.

To answer your first question regarding value, we're not going to give you guidance. We never give guidance on value, thank God. But our ambition just to give you our state of mind is that the value effect should be, we hope, will be better than in 2010. We are not worried about being doomed to have a value effect that would deteriorate over time. On the contrary, in 2011, we have great innovation coming from all divisions, and we believe that it is through innovation that we get the value effect and we believe that we're going to be able to regain some of the value effect in a positive way. And we're going to ask your question from room two. This gentleman has been waiting for an extremely long time.

You've already answered, partially the answer that I wanted to ask you. Looking at your operating margin per geographic zone would be interesting because if you look at the overall margin, I mean there is obviously the outcome of the balancing between the gross margins of the three major branches that you've identified. You've already answered on two points.

You said that the margin for emerging markets should continue increasing, even though it is already higher than the margin that you have in America. And you also said that the European margin should not be used as a benchmark, because it was inflated artificially by some specific conditions. Now I have additional follow-on questions if I may.

First of all, the margin for emerging markets, should it increase or will it increase in the next five years, will it increase by two or three points as it has done over the last three or four years? And that would mean possibly that the benchmark for all of the regions would probably be to the tune of 20% if we assume that there is an anomaly regarding the present European margin.

And the second question that I would like to ask is as follows. The American margin which concerns a region that can be compared to the European region in general, the American region is structurally shrinking or reduced by three or four points. Is that a durable and structural phenomenon, is that due to the structure of the product, is that due to the conditions of competition or marketing conditions or phenomenon of the same type, which means that for a long time, we will have a rather big difference between the American margins on the one hand and the European margins on the other that would serve as benchmarks reduced possibly by two or three points as we said for the actual benchmark.

Regarding the second part of your question, the American margin, if you look at 2010, we see that the American margin can increase – profitability can increase. America is a market that I'm very familiar with. It's a highly competitive market. A number of our competitors on the American market, in some sectors, are not very profitable, if you know what I mean.

But we are firmly convinced as for emerging markets that we can continue increasing regularly our margins in this market. It also depends on how we can establish the right balance between all of our activities. But it is our ambition to increase our margin regularly in the American markets. We are currently doing that. We have Mr. Frédéric Rozé in America, and we've urged him to undertake very strong action in order to optimize the industrial facilities, in order to optimize the cost structures of the American operations, and I'm sure that it's going to continue delivering good results in terms of profitability.

Regarding the emerging markets zone, our objective is to improve margins progressively in all of these countries. As Christian Mulliez was saying, we're no longer at A stage where we have small businesses with high cost and low critical mass. In most countries, we have very large projects with very big critical – large critical mass that can give you a very high return on your investment and the new subsidiaries that we're creating are not very costly. We're talking about more – bigger countries and we try to establish our presence there gradually. So all of this paves the way, we believe, for regular and sustainable improvements in the profit margin of the Group in general.

I have an add-on question here. Can we consider that the European margin is indeed the benchmark and it should be roughly 22% minus, possibly 10% that would correspond to the artificial marketing conditions of your products in this area? So within the next four or five years, an average gross margin of 20% for the United States and emerging countries, could 20% be considered as the benchmark or is that going to happen in the next few years you believe?
I'm sure that Christian will give you a very specific answer to that.

Yes, I'll give you a very specific and credible answer. It is important to strike the right balance between growth and profitability. Profitability is the outcome of growth. But we don't want to have too high profitability because that would mean that we would take fewer initiatives to support growth and the growth of our markets in emerging markets, and this is not something that we will do. So the growth of profitability in emerging markets will happen in due time at our own rhythm. Yes, but as Jean-Jacques was saying, 20% is not out of the question. It is not impossible in the long run. Was there any other question?

Christian Schubert from the Frankfurt . I have two questions. One of the market shares, first of all, do you have figures that indicate the market shares and how do you compare with your competitors Unilever, Procter & Gamble? So maybe sector-by-sector, you could give us an answer or compare to your competitors.

Now another question, if I've understood well, in the personal care sector, P&G has won quite a lot of market share, so what do you think about the Beiersdorf Company by the way, talking about personal care product?

Jean-Jacques would tell you exactly about the market shares that we have. We don't like to talk about our competitors. The only thing I can tell is that competitors – the two competitors that you quoted yourself, our performance in 2010 was better than theirs.
And that would seem to indicate that we are the ones who won market shares. Jean-Jacques, maybe you can explain where and how we did win these market shares.

We're not going to indicate market shares in a very detailed fashion, but in Western Europe, we had indicated the market shares in the past. So we're between 27% and 28%, in total, North America roughly 20%, emerging markets or new markets, roughly 9% market share. And by the way, this shows that there is a lot of margin potential in the emerging markets.

Western markets, as I told, 30%, 20% in North America and 9% in emerging markets. Talking about the market shares of our competitors, I don't know, but there are available sources for this kind of information. I mean, I would send you to consult these sources. It depends on which markets you are talking about and how you're looking at these figures. You can look at the different titles, if you don't have these sources, we'll make them available to you and you will see that we are doing quite a bit better than our competitors.

I come from JPMorgan. Productivity gains and cost efficiencies over the past couple of years, can you tell us what are you aiming to achieve and what are you targeting in next year? And second, a small one on the de-stocking comment that you made in the U.S. Has things improved since December or has it got to worse? How intense de-stocking did you see in U.S.? Thanks.

We didn't say that there was a de-stocking in the U.S. I just said that we should not extrapolate the fact that the growth rate was a bit lower than the quarter before to extrapolate it for the next quarter. So it's not a question of de-stocking, it's a question of phasing, of launches or – et cetera. So what we have seen is that the latest news from the U.S. is that the evolution of the consumption was okay, and we expect a good beginning of the year in North America for L'Oréal. And so, we are quite positive and optimistic regarding North America in 2011. And your first question was?
Productivity.

Productivity. Productivity, in fact we had a record year in term of productivity in 2010 and we expect to have another very, very good year in 2011. So we think that we will be able again, and I speak in front of Jean-Philippe Blanpain who is in charge of achieving it. He confirms it that we will have another very good year in term of productivity. In fact that the new – the growth of the volume, the units plus the new industrial strategy that we are putting in place is really paying-off in term of productivity and in term of cost of goods. So we are quite ambitious there.
Right.
Just two add-on questions. Regarding Brazil, could you give us the sales per business segment, the enlarged business segment?

I'll give you the overall figure unless I don't think that we should indicate this by business segment because this kind of data is confidential. €700 million in Brazil in sales, which is – I mean you may guess of course from that, Consumer Products probably account for 65% or 70% of the overall sales – of the overall business.
I'm sorry I didn't hear the last bit.
€700 million with 65% to 70% attributable to Consumer Products.

Second question now on acquisitions. In light of the inflation, increased prices in the Cosmetics sector which is very active, when you say – you talk about acquisitions, are you talking about tactical operations here or would the Group be ready to engage in larger scale operations?

I wouldn't say that tactical is – or strategic and significant are two different things. It's very easy to engage in acquisitions. You can buy a company every day. There are companies up for sale in the market every single day at any kind of price. And I can tell you that there is something very clear that I can tell you here. All the acquisitions that were made this year by our competitors are acquisitions that we looked into, all of them. We looked into all of these acquisition projects, and we looked at them in great depth. And obviously, if we didn't engage in these acquisitions, there were good reasons for this, as you can infer from our behavior. So it's not because our competitors are engaging in a lot of acquisitions, but it's necessarily a good thing. Point number one.

And secondly, as far as we're concerned, the problem is to find so-called strategic acquisitions. Sometimes we have a significant – an important or significant acquisition which is the small scale acquisition. Sanoflore, for example, is a bold acquisition, but it's a great brand, a great brand that can become a leading global brand. If you take a small acquisition that we did this year called SE, it's a small nail varnish brand. Our ambition is to turn it into the world leader in nail varnish. It will take as long as it takes, five years, 10 years, 15 years, 20 or 25 years. But it's also strategic importance despite the scale.

So the issue in terms of acquisition is to target exactly, to pinpoint the complementary products for our portfolio. And we need to engage in acquisitions that will offer the highest middle-term and long-term potential.

Okay. It is now 5 past 12, and that was the last question unless there is another one burning, this doesn't seem to be the case. So I'd like to thank you very much for your questions. And we will have a little reception, and you'll be able to meet with all of the members of the Executive Board.
